ingredients:
For the Rice:

2 cups Basmati rice, washed and soaked for 30 minutes
4 cups water
1-2 bay leaves
4-5 whole cloves
4-5 whole green cardamom pods
1 cinnamon stick
Salt to taste

For the Chicken:
1 kg chicken, cut into pieces
1 cup plain yogurt
1 tablespoon ginger-garlic paste
1 teaspoon turmeric powder
1 teaspoon red chili powder
Salt to taste

For the Biryani:
3 large onions, thinly sliced
1 cup cooking oil or ghee
1 cup chopped tomatoes
1/2 cup fresh coriander leaves, chopped
1/2 cup fresh mint leaves, chopped
1 tablespoon biryani masala (available at Indian grocery stores)
Saffron strands soaked in warm milk (optional)
Fried onions for garnish (optional)
itemDescription:
Preparing the Rice:
In a large pot, bring 4 cups of water to a boil.
Add the soaked and drained Basmati rice, bay leaves, cloves, cardamom pods, cinnamon stick, and salt.
Cook the rice until it is 70-80% cooked. The grains should still be firm. Drain the water and set aside.

Marinating the Chicken:
In a bowl, mix the chicken pieces with yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt.
Allow the chicken to marinate for at least 30 minutes or longer for better flavor.

Cooking the Chicken:
In a large, heavy-bottomed pan, heat oil or ghee over medium heat.
Add the sliced onions and sauté until golden brown. Remove half of the fried onions for garnishing.
Add the marinated chicken to the pan and cook until it is browned and the oil separates.
Add chopped tomatoes, biryani masala, fresh coriander leaves, and mint leaves. Cook until the tomatoes are soft and the chicken is cooked through.

Layering and Dum Cooking:
In a heavy-bottomed pan or a biryani pot, layer half of the partially cooked rice at the bottom.
Spread the cooked chicken mixture evenly over the rice layer.
Top with the remaining rice, spreading it evenly.
Drizzle saffron-soaked milk (optional) over the rice. You can also add a few drops of food coloring to the milk for a vibrant look.
Sprinkle the reserved fried onions over the top.
Cover the pot tightly with a lid or foil. Cook on low heat (dum) for about 20-25 minutes. This allows the flavors to meld, and the rice cooks completely.

Serve:
Gently fluff the biryani with a fork.
Serve hot, garnished with additional fresh coriander leaves and mint leaves.
Enjoy the biryani with raita or a side salad.

ingredients:
For Chana Masala (Chickpea Curry):
1 cup dried chickpeas (soaked overnight and boiled until tender)
2 tablespoons oil
1 large onion, finely chopped
2 tomatoes, chopped
1 teaspoon ginger-garlic paste
1 teaspoon cumin seeds
1 teaspoon coriander powder
1/2 teaspoon turmeric powder
1/2 teaspoon red chili powder
1/2 teaspoon garam masala
Salt to taste

Fresh coriander leaves for garnish
For Halwa (Semolina Pudding):
1 cup semolina (suji or sooji)
1/2 cup ghee (clarified butter)
1 cup sugar
2 cups water
1/2 teaspoon cardamom powder
A handful of chopped nuts (almonds, cashews, pistachios) for garnish

For Puri (Deep-Fried Bread):
2 cups whole wheat flour
Water for kneading
Oil for deep frying
itemDescription:
For Chana Masala:
Heat oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté until the raw smell disappears.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they become soft.
Add coriander powder, turmeric powder, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt. Cook the spices for a couple of minutes.
Add boiled chickpeas and mix well. Let it simmer for 10-15 minutes until the flavors meld.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and keep it warm.

For Halwa:
Heat ghee in a pan. Add semolina and roast it on low-medium heat until it turns golden brown and releases a nutty aroma.
In a separate saucepan, heat water and sugar until the sugar dissolves. Add this sugar water to the roasted semolina slowly, stirring continuously to avoid lumps.
Cook the mixture until it thickens. Add cardamom powder and chopped nuts. Mix well.
Continue cooking until the halwa reaches your desired consistency. It should be smooth and not too dry.
Keep the halwa warm.

For Puri:
Mix whole wheat flour with water to make a soft, pliable dough.
Divide the dough into small balls and roll them into flat circles.
Heat oil in a deep pan for frying.
Fry the puris until they puff up and turn golden brown.
Remove excess oil by placing the puris on paper towels.

Assembling Halwa Puri:
Serve Chana Masala, Halwa, and Puri on a plate.
Enjoy Halwa Puri by tearing a piece of Puri, spooning some Chana Masala onto it, and finishing with a bite of Halwa.

ingredients:
For the Rice:
2 cups basmati rice, soaked for 30 minutes and drained
4 cups water
2 tablespoons oil
1-2 cinnamon sticks
4-5 whole cloves
4-5 whole green cardamom pods
Salt to taste

For the Meat:
1 kg lamb or chicken, cut into pieces
2 tablespoons vegetable oil
1 large onion, finely chopped
2 teaspoons ginger-garlic paste
1 teaspoon ground coriander
1 teaspoon ground cumin
1 teaspoon turmeric powder
Salt and pepper to taste

For Garnish:
1 cup sliced carrots
1/2 cup raisins (optional)
1/2 cup slivered almonds or chopped pistachios
Chopped fresh cilantro or mint for garnish
itemDescription:
Preparing the Rice:
In a large pot, bring 4 cups of water to a boil.
Add soaked and drained basmati rice to the boiling water along with oil, cinnamon sticks, cloves, green cardamom pods, and salt.
Cook the rice until it's about 70-80% cooked. The grains should still be firm. Drain the water and set aside.

Cooking the Meat:
In a separate pot, heat vegetable oil over medium heat.
Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté until the raw smell disappears.
Add the meat pieces and cook until they are browned on all sides.
Add ground coriander, ground cumin, turmeric powder, salt, and pepper. Mix well to coat the meat with the spices.
Pour in enough water to cover the meat. Cover and simmer until the meat is tender and cooked through.

Layering and Dum Cooking:
In the pot with the cooked meat, spread half of the partially cooked rice evenly.
Sprinkle sliced carrots, raisins (if using), and slivered almonds or chopped pistachios over the rice layer.
Top with the remaining rice, spreading it evenly.
Cover the pot tightly with a lid or foil. Cook on low heat (dum) for about 20-25 minutes. This allows the flavors to meld, and the rice cooks completely.

Serving:
Gently fluff the rice with a fork, mixing in the meat and garnishes.
Serve the Kabuli Pulao on a platter, garnished with chopped fresh cilantro or mint.

ingredients:
For the Nihari Spice Mix (Nihari Masala):
2 tablespoons coriander seeds
1 tablespoon fennel seeds
1 tablespoon cumin seeds
1 tablespoon whole black peppercorns
1 tablespoon whole cloves
1 tablespoon green cardamom pods
2-3 black cardamom pods
1 cinnamon stick (about 2 inches)
1 teaspoon turmeric powder
1 teaspoon ground nutmeg

For the Nihari:
1 kg beef stew meat or beef shanks
3 tablespoons ghee or oil
2 large onions, thinly sliced
2 tablespoons ginger-garlic paste
2 tablespoons Nihari Masala (from above)
1 teaspoon red chili powder (adjust to taste)
1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon
1/2 teaspoon ground cloves
Salt to taste
8 cups water
2 tablespoons wheat flour (optional, for thickening)

For Garnish:
Fresh coriander leaves, chopped
Ginger slices
Green chilies, sliced
Lemon wedges
itemDescription:
1. Prepare Nihari Masala:
Dry roast coriander seeds, fennel seeds, cumin seeds, black peppercorns, cloves, green cardamom pods, black cardamom pods, and cinnamon stick until fragrant. Grind the roasted spices along with turmeric powder and nutmeg to form a fine powder. This is your Nihari Masala.

2. Brown the Meat:
In a large, heavy-bottomed pot, heat ghee or oil over medium heat. Add sliced onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for a minute until the raw smell disappears.
Add beef stew meat or beef shanks and brown the meat on all sides.

3. Add Spices and Nihari Masala:
Add Nihari Masala, red chili powder, ground cinnamon, ground cloves, and salt to the browned meat. Mix well to coat the meat with the spices.

4. Slow Cook the Nihari:
Pour in water and bring the mixture to a boil.
Once boiling, reduce the heat to low, cover the pot, and let it simmer for at least 4-6 hours. The longer the simmering, the richer the flavors.

5. Optional Thickening:
If you prefer a thicker consistency, mix wheat flour with a little water to form a smooth paste. Add this paste to the simmering pot and stir well. Cook for an additional 30 minutes.

6. Garnish and Serve:
Once the meat is tender and the broth is rich, garnish the Nihari with chopped coriander leaves, ginger slices, and green chilies.
Serve hot with naan or steamed rice. Offer lemon wedges on the side for squeezing over the Nihari.

ingredients:
4 to 6 pieces of cow or goat trotters (cleaned and split)
1 cup wheat grains (soaked overnight)
2 large onions (finely sliced)
4 tomatoes (chopped)
1/2 cup yogurt
1/2 cup cooking oil or ghee (clarified butter)
1 tablespoon ginger paste
1 tablespoon garlic paste
1 tablespoon cumin powder
1 tablespoon coriander powder
1 teaspoon turmeric powder
1 teaspoon red chili powder (adjust to taste)
Salt to taste

Fresh coriander leaves (for garnish)
Fresh ginger slices (for garnish)
Garam masala (whole spices) for baghar/tempering (optional)
itemDescription:
Clean and Soak the Trotters:
Clean the trotters thoroughly and soak them in water for a few hours or overnight to remove any excess blood.

Boil Trotters and Wheat:
In a large pot, add the trotters and soaked wheat grains.
Add enough water to cover the trotters and wheat.
Bring it to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and simmer until the trotters and wheat are tender. This may take several hours, and you can use a pressure cooker to expedite the process.

Prepare the Masala:
In a separate pan, heat oil or ghee over medium heat.
Add sliced onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger paste and garlic paste, and cook until the raw smell disappears.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they are soft and the oil starts to separate.
Add yogurt, cumin powder, coriander powder, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt. Cook the masala until the oil separates from the spices.

Combine Trotters, Wheat, and Masala:
Once the trotters and wheat are tender, add the prepared masala to the pot.
Mix everything well and let it simmer on low heat for at least another 30 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld.

Prepare Baghar (Optional):
In a small pan, heat a few tablespoons of oil or ghee.
Add garam masala (whole spices) and let them sizzle for a few seconds.
Pour this baghar over the simmering Siri Paye for added flavor.

Serve:
Garnish the Siri Paye with fresh coriander leaves and ginger slices.
Serve hot with naan or crusty bread.

ingredients:
For the stuffing:
1 cup long-grain rice
1/2 cup pine nuts
1/2 cup currants or raisins
1/4 cup olive oil
1 large onion, finely chopped
2 cloves garlic, minced
1/4 cup chopped fresh dill
1/4 cup chopped fresh mint
Salt and pepper to taste

For the grape leaves:
1 jar of grape leaves in brine (about 60-70 leaves)
Water, for rinsing grape leaves

For cooking:
1 lemon, juiced
1/4 cup olive oil
2 cups vegetable broth or water
itemDescription:
Prepare the Grape Leaves:
If using jarred grape leaves, rinse them thoroughly under cold running water to remove excess salt.
Gently separate the leaves and trim any tough stems.

Prepare the Filling:
In a skillet, heat 1/4 cup of olive oil over medium heat.
Add chopped onions and garlic, sauté until translucent.
Add pine nuts and sauté until they are lightly golden.
Stir in the rice and cook for 2-3 minutes until the rice is coated with oil.
Add currants or raisins, chopped dill, chopped mint, salt, and pepper. Stir well and cook for another 2-3 minutes.
Remove the mixture from heat and let it cool.

Assemble the Dolma:
Place a grape leaf shiny side down on a flat surface.
Add a small amount of the rice mixture (about a tablespoon) to the center of the leaf.
Fold the sides of the leaf over the filling and then roll it tightly from the bottom to the top, creating a cigar-like shape.

Cook the Dolma:
Arrange the dolma in a large pot, placing them close together to prevent them from unraveling during cooking.
Mix the lemon juice and 1/4 cup of olive oil and pour it over the dolma.
Pour vegetable broth or water over the dolma until they are just covered.
Place a heavy plate or an upside-down bowl on top of the dolma to keep them in place while cooking.
Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer for about 45-60 minutes, or until the rice is cooked and the grape leaves are tender.

Serve:
Once cooked, let the dolma cool before serving.
Serve with a side of tzatziki sauce or yogurt, and garnish with lemon wedges if desired.

ingredients:
For the Napa Cabbage:
1 large napa cabbage
1 cup coarse sea salt

For the Kimchi Paste:
1 medium-sized Korean radish (or daikon radish), julienned
5-6 green onions, chopped
1 cup Korean red pepper flakes (gochugaru)
1/2 cup fish sauce
1/3 cup soy sauce
1/4 cup sugar
1 tablespoon minced garlic
1 tablespoon minced ginger
1 teaspoon salted shrimp paste (saeujeot) - optional but traditional
1 teaspoon sugar (for brining the radish)
itemDescription:
Prepare the Napa Cabbage:
Cut the napa cabbage in half lengthwise and then into quarters.
Dissolve 1 cup of coarse sea salt in a large bowl of water.
Submerge the cabbage quarters in the saltwater, making sure the saltwater gets between the leaves.
Let the cabbage soak for 1-2 hours, turning occasionally.

Rinse and Drain:
Rinse the cabbage thoroughly under cold running water to remove excess salt.
Gently squeeze out any excess water and let it drain.

Prepare the Kimchi Paste:
Julienne the Korean radish and mix it with 1 teaspoon of sugar. Let it sit for about 15 minutes, then drain any released liquid.
In a large bowl, combine the julienned radish, chopped green onions, Korean red pepper flakes, fish sauce, soy sauce, sugar, minced garlic, minced ginger, and salted shrimp paste (if using). Mix well to form a paste.

Combine Cabbage and Paste:
Spread the kimchi paste between the cabbage leaves, making sure to coat each layer.

Pack into Jars:
Pack the kimchi into clean glass jars, pressing it down to remove air pockets.
Leave some space at the top of the jars to allow for expansion during fermentation.

Fermentation:
Seal the jars and let them sit at room temperature for about 1-5 days, depending on your desired level of fermentation.
Burp the jars daily to release gases produced during fermentation.
Once it reaches the desired taste, refrigerate the kimchi to slow down the fermentation process.

Serve:
Kimchi can be served as a side dish, in rice bowls, or used in various Korean recipes.

ingredients:
For the Falafel:
1 cup dried chickpeas (soaked overnight and drained)
1 small onion, roughly chopped
3 cloves garlic
1/2 cup fresh parsley, chopped
1 teaspoon ground cumin
1 teaspoon ground coriander
1/2 teaspoon cayenne pepper (adjust to taste)
Salt and pepper to taste
1 teaspoon baking powder
3-4 tablespoons all-purpose flour or chickpea flour (as needed)
Vegetable oil for frying

For Serving:
Pita bread or flatbreads
Tahini sauce or yogurt sauce
Chopped tomatoes, cucumbers, and lettuce
itemDescription:
Prepare Chickpeas:
Soak dried chickpeas in water overnight. Drain well before using.

Make Falafel Mixture:
In a food processor, combine soaked and drained chickpeas, chopped onion, garlic, fresh parsley, cumin, coriander, cayenne pepper, salt, and pepper.
Pulse the mixture until everything is finely ground, but not pureed. You may need to scrape down the sides of the processor bowl to ensure an even mix.

Add Baking Powder and Flour:
Add baking powder and start by adding 3 tablespoons of flour. Pulse to combine.
Check the consistency of the mixture. It should be able to hold together when you squeeze it. If it's too wet, add more flour, one tablespoon at a time, until the mixture is easy to shape.

Shape Falafel:
Scoop out small portions of the mixture and shape them into small patties or balls. You can use your hands or a falafel scoop.

Fry the Falafel:
Heat vegetable oil in a deep pan to around 350°F (175°C).
Carefully place the falafel into the hot oil, frying until they are golden brown and crispy on the outside. This usually takes about 3-4 minutes per batch.
Use a slotted spoon to remove the falafel from the oil and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to absorb excess oil.

Serve:
Serve the Turkish falafel in pita bread or flatbreads.
Add chopped tomatoes, cucumbers, and lettuce.
Drizzle with tahini sauce or yogurt sauce.
